Graphical abstract CoFe alloy nanoparticles with ultra-high-density are exsolved on the (PrBa)0.95(Fe0.8Co0.1Nb0.1)2O5+ δ (PBFCN0.1) surface under reducing atmosphere, achieving high performance when H2 or C2H6 is used as fuel. Nanoparticles anchored on the perovskite surface have gained considerable attention for their wide-ranging applications in heterogeneous catalysis and energy conversion due to their robust and integrated structural configuration. Herein, we employ controlled Co doping to effectively enhance the nanoparticle exsolution process in layered perovskite ferrites materials. CoFe alloy nanoparticles with ultra-high-density are exsolved on the (PrBa)0.95(Fe0.8Co0.1Nb0.1)2O5+ δ (PBFCN0.1) surface under reducing atmosphere, providing significant amounts of reaction sites and good durability for hydrocarbon catalysis. Under a reducing atmosphere, cobalt facilitates the reduction of iron cations within PBFCN0.1, leading to the formation of CoFe alloy nanoparticles. This formation is accompanied by a cation exchange process, wherein, with the increase in temperature, partial cobalt ions are substituted by iron. Meanwhile, Co doping significantly enhance the electrical conductivity due to the stronger covalency of the CoO bond compared with FeO bond. A single cell with the configuration of PBFCN0.1-Sm0.2Ce0.8O1.9 (SDC)|SDC|Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3− δ (BSCF)-SDC achieves an extremely low polarization resistance of 0.0163 Ω cm2 and a high peak power density of 740 mW cm−2 at 800 °C. The cell also shows stable operation for 120 h in H2 with a constant current density of 285 mA cm−2. Furthermore, employing wet C2H6 as fuel, the cell demonstrates remarkable performance, achieving peak power densities of 455 mW cm−2 at 800 °C and 320 mW cm−2 at 750 °C, marking improvements of 36% and 70% over the cell with (PrBa)0.95(Fe0.9Nb0.1)2O5+ δ (PBFN)-SDC at these respective temperatures. This discovery emphasizes how temperature influences alloy nanoparticles exsolution within doped layered perovskite ferrites materials, paving the way for the development of high-performance ceramic fuel cell anodes. Keywords Solid oxide fuel cell Anode Ethane fuel Nanoparticle Exsolution Layered perovskite Ferrites 1 Introduction To diminish the reliance of modern society on fossil fuels and fulfill the threefold objectives of Ecology, Economy, and Efficiency, the adoption of renewable energy sources and advancements in energy storage technologies have become pivotal [1,2]. As a representation of green devices, solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) possess the remarkable capability to directly transform the chemical energy of fuels into electric power [3]. This technology has garnered significant attention for its high efficiency, environmentally-friendly operations, and fuel flexibility particularly in the context of a carbon–neutral future [4]. Hydrogen is a popular choice for fuel cell devices, which stems from its outstanding benefits such as high energy density and rapid kinetics leading to quick start-up and dynamic load-following capabilities [5–7]. However, widespread adoption of hydrogen may bring some challenges, particularly in its storage and production. Its low liquefaction temperature of −253 °C necessitates sophisticated and energy-intensive cooling systems [8,9]. Furthermore, the high costs associated with producing pure hydrogen, especially through low-emission methods like water electrolysis, also pose significant barriers [10]. Hence, this elevates the appeal of carbon containing fuels like methane, ethane, propane, syngas, and even solid carbon for SOFCs [11,12]. In a typical SOFC, a dense electrolyte is sandwiched between a porous anode and cathode. When powered by hydrocarbon fuels, the anode becomes dramatically important to the electrochemical performance of the cells. As a result, the materials chosen for the anode must demonstrate a good ionic conductivity, appropriate thermal expansion coefficient, superior catalytic activity for hydrocarbon fuels, and resistance to carbon deposition [13]. However, the commercially-used Ni-YSZ (yttrium-stabilized-zirconia) anode displays limited resistance to coking [14]. When hydrocarbon fuels are employed, this can result in swift performance decline due to the obstruction of electrochemical reaction sites by coke and the enlargement of nickel grains [15]. In this case, researchers have developed several strategies like alloying, introducing noble metals into Ni or adapting catalyst layers to enhance the carbon resistance of Ni-based cermet anodes [16]. However, these approaches often hindered by factors like inadequate activity or elevated costs. Given these challenges, the development of functional anode materials with resistance against carbon deposition is essential for direct-hydrocarbon SOFC [17]. Certain ceramic materials, exhibiting both ionic and electronic conduction, could be tailored for specific properties due to their flexible crystal structures [18]. This unique property allows them to confront the demands of rigorous anodic conditions and ensure consistent performance, even in hydrocarbon fuels. For example, perovskite oxides with appropriately tailored have been reported to display good catalytic performance in the presence of hydrocarbon fuels. Single perovskite oxides such as La0.2Sr0.8TiO3+ δ (LST) [8], La1− x Sr x Cr1− x Fe x O3− δ (LSCrF) [19], La0.75Sr0.25Cr0.5Mn0.5O3− δ (LSCM) [20] have been developed as anode materials. However, the electrochemical performance of these materials alone is unsatisfactory compared with that of Ni-based cermet anodes. To address the issue, layered perovskites with A-site ordered like GdBaMn2O5+ x [21] and PrBaMn2O5+ δ [22], have emerged as promising alternatives. These structures can accommodate significant interstitial oxygen, leading to a high concentration of oxygen vacancies, rapid surface exchange kinetics, and efficient mixed transport of ions and electrons. For instance, Ding et al. developed a A-site deficient ceramic oxide (PrBa)0.95(Fe0.9Nb0.1)2O5+ δ (PBFN) as anode material for the catalysis of hydrocarbon fuel [23]. The anode displays promising redox-cycling stability, good electrochemical oxidation activity and coking tolerance in wet and dry CH4. However, the presence of numerous oxide peaks in the X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern indicates that this material is not a pure perovskite oxide, potentially affecting its conductivity and catalytic activity. Moreover, the exsolved nanoparticles anchored on the perovskite surface have been regarded as an effective way to enlarge the electrochemical sites for hydrocarbon oxidation [24]. Nevertheless, the Fe element is more challenging to exsolve from the perovskite structure compared to Ni and Co [25]. Therefore, solving the exsolution and purity problems of nanoparticles is expected to further enhance the catalytic activity of PBFN. To address the inherent challenge of Fe exsolution, researchers have explored to reduce the segregation energy of Fe in perovskite by doping with Ni or Co [26]. Du et al. reported the formation of Ni-Fe alloy particles on Ni-doped Sr2FeMo0.65Ni0.35O6− δ after reduction, contrasting with the undoped perovskite, which remained stable without exsolution phenomenon under reduction [27]. Bao et al. demonstrated that doping Co into Sr2Fe1.35Mo0.45Co0.2O6− δ (SFMO) lattice can tune the overall reducibility of the materials to form Co-Fe alloy nanoparticles [28]. In addition, they found metallic Co exsolved from the perovskite before Fe, facilitating cation deficiency and oxygen vacancies, thereby lowering the energy barrier for Fe exsolution. While the phenomenon of exsolution in single-metal nanoparticles has been thoroughly explored, the understanding of exsolution processes in alloy nanoparticles with diverse segregation energies remains limited. Further detailed studies are necessary to elucidate the morphological and structural evolution mechanisms underlying alloy formation to design efficient metal-oxide interfaces for solid oxide fuel cells. Herein, we unveil a refined strategy leveraging trace amounts of Co doping to address the challenges of purity and nanoparticle exsolution inherent in PBFN materials. The synthesized (PrBa)0.95(Fe0.8Co0.1Nb0.1)2O5+ δ (PBFCN0.1), which exhibit a pure layered perovskite phase, showcases a high electrocatalytic activity and excellent durability under hydrocarbon operation conditions. Furthermore, CoFe alloy nanoparticles with ultra-high-density are exsolved on the PBFCN0.1 surface under the reduction atmosphere, providing more reaction sites and good durability for the catalysis of wet ethane. At a reduced temperature of approximately 500 °C, CoFe alloy nanoparticles emerge from the parent perovskite framework, exhibiting a lower Fe concentration due to its high segregation energy. With increasing temperatures, partial Co ions are replaced by Fe, leading to a transformation of the nanoparticles from larger sizes to ultra-densely decorated, smaller counterparts. When the PBFCN0.1 is tested in a Sm0.2Ce0.8O1.9 (SDC) electrolyte-based single cell with a configuration of PBFCN0.1-SDC|SDC|BSCF-SDC, the cell demonstrates high performances in both hydrogen atmosphere (e.g., a typical peak power density of 738 mW cm−2 at 800 °C and wet ethane atmosphere (e.g., a typical peak power density of 455 mW cm−2 at 800 °C). Notably, the performance under wet ethane atmosphere is significantly improved by 36%–70% compared to the original PBFN (e.g., a typical peak power density of 334 mW cm−2 at 800 °C). This study offers a promising approach to enhance nanoparticle exsolution in layered perovskite ferrites, paving the way for the development of high-performance ceramic fuel cell anodes. 2 Experimental 2.1 Anode preparation (PrBa)0.95(Fe0.8Co0.1Nb0.1)2O5+ δ (PBFCNx, x = 0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3) and BSCF powders were synthesized using C10H16N2O8 (EDTA)-C6H8O7 (citric acid) combustion approach. Initially, stoichiometrically measured nitrate precursors from Aladdin Chemical Reagent were uniformly dissolved in deionized water. Then EDTA and C6H8O7·H2O were incorporated into the mixture, and the pH was subsequently fine-tuned using ammonia. The solution was stirred continuously until it transformed into a sol–gel-like appearance. The gel was then dried in an aerated oven at 200 °C, for 6 h, resulting in a black precursor. Finally, the precursor was calcined at 1050 °C for 5 h in air to obtain the PBFCNx powders. The reduction of PBFCNx powders was achieved by exposing them to pure hydrogen at 800 °C, maintained for a period of 2 h. 2.2 Property characterization The crystallinity structure of the powders was characterized using XRD (Rigaku Ultima IV). Analysis of the lattice parameters was conducted through Rietveld refinement, utilizing the FullProf software for detailed evaluation. During the hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), around 60 mg of the powders was placed in a pure H2 atmosphere, maintaining a stable flow rate (50 mL min−1) at 300 °C for 60 min. Subsequently, after cooling down to room temperature, the environment inside the reactor was changed to a mixture of 10 vol% H2-Ar. The reactor was then gradually heated to 800 °C, with a controlled heating rate of 10 °C min−1. SEM (TESCAN MIRA LMS) was conducted to observe the morphology of the powders as well as the cross-sectional structure of the single cells. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) on an FEI Tecnai G2 F20 instrument, along with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), was utilized to examine the morphology and elemental distribution of the phase components. The Valence states of element on the material surface were identified and characterized by Avantage software using results obtained from X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) conducted on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha system. The X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) measurements were conducted at the BL7D station of the Pohang Synchrotron Radiation Facility in Republic of Korea, operating at an energy of 2.5 GeV and a maximum current capacity of 250 mA. The processing of the XAS data was executed using the ATHENA program, a key component of the IFEFFIT software suite (version 1.2.12), adhering to standardized procedures. To assess the electrical conductivity of the materials, the PBFCNx powders were pressed into bars (approximately 5 mm × 2 mm × 20 mm) through uniaxial pressing, followed by sintering at 1200 °C for 5 h. For conductivity tests, silver wire and paste served as electrical connections, with measurements conducted by a four-probe DC method employing a Keithley 2400 source meter. 2.3 Cell fabrication The single cells using for experimental tests can be summarized as PBFCNx-SDC|SDC|BSCF-SDC. To prepare a dense SDC electrolyte pellet, 0.2 g SDC powder (Fuel Cell, USA) was pressed and then sintered at 1300 °C for 10 h. The cathode slurry was prepared by mixing BSCF and SDC powders in isopropyl alcohol with the ratio of 7:3. For the anode slurry, a similar process was employed, where the PBFCNx and SDC powders are mixed in isopropyl alcohol, also maintaining the same 7:3 ratio. Then, the cathode and anode slurry are sprayed on each side of the SDC pellet to form a three-layered structure. Finally, the pellet was heated at 900 °C for 2 h, resulting in a tight contact between the electrodes and the electrolyte. For optimal electron collection, the electrodes were coated with silver paste, which is applied in an intricate net-like pattern. To evaluate the performance of the single cell, it was sealed onto the quartz tube using silver paste as the adhesive. This arrangement left the anode exposed to the external environment, facilitating precise testing conditions. 2.4 Electrochemical test The electrochemical performance of the single cells was assessed by a Solartron 1287 Electrochemical Workstation. Specifically, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) spectra were obtained by configuring the voltage amplitude at 30 mV and selecting a frequency spectrum that ranged from 0.1 Hz to 100 kHz under open-circuit voltage. The current-power density (I-P) and current-voltage (I-V) curves of the single cells were collected by using a four-probe method via Keithley 2420 source meter. During the test, H2 or wet C2H6 was supplied to the anode chamber, while ambient air served as the cathode atmosphere. The flow rate for both H2 and C2H6 fuel was maintained at 80 mL min−1 (Standard Temperature and Pressure (STP)), ensuring optimal conditions for the evaluation. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Phase composition and microstructure The phase structures of the synthesized Co-doped PBFN perovskite oxides, synthesized using the combustion method, were first characterized using XRD. As illustrated in Fig. 1 (a), a subtle Co doping in PBFCN triggers a transition from a mixed phase, inclusive of Pr2O3 oxide (JCPDS#00-037-0825), to a purely layered phase (JCPDS#00-057-0089). Shift of peaks indicate Co doping could lead to the lattice contraction of PBFN (Fig. S1) [29]. This phenomenon can be attributed to the relatively smaller ionic radius of Co3+ (0.061 nm) compared to that of Fe3+ (0.064 nm), indicating that the lattice contraction is likely a result of Co3+ partially replacing Fe3+ at the B-site of PBFN. Consequently, this substitution causes the PBCFN peak to shift towards a higher angle. In addition, excessive Co doping (x = 0.3) introduces an additional phase, BaNbO3 (JCPDS#01-072-2106), in the XRD pattern, suggesting that to maintain a pure perovskite structure, Co doping should not surpass 30 mol%. After reduction at 800 °C for 2 h in H2 atmosphere, reduced PBFN and PBFCN0.1 sample exhibit a dual-phase structure including the main phase of layered perovskite, accompanied by a secondary phase (Fig. 1b). In the case of the reduced PBFN, the secondary phase is metallic Fe (JCPDS#03-065-5099), whereas for the PBFCN0.1 sample, the secondary phase is CoFe alloy (JCPDS#96-900-4230) (Fig. 1c). Based on the XRD patterns of the reduced PBFCN x samples, we calculated the lattice parameters of them via rietveld refinement analysis (Fig. S2, Tables S1–S4). The fitting parameters, specifically R wp, R p, and GOF, affirm a trustworthy fit for the four perovskites. The reduced PBFCN0.2 and PBFCN0.3 samples exhibit significant decomposition, where PrBa3Fe2O7.4 (JCPDS#00-048-0775), Pr2O3 oxide (JCPDS#00-037-0825) and CoO (JCPDS#01-070-2856) emerge in the refined XRD profiles, indicating that an excess of cobalt adversely affects the structural stability under the reduction conditions. The reduced PBFCN0.1 sample displays an decreased cell volume compared to the reduced PBFN, aligning with the characteristics observed in the samples prior to reduction. The reduced PBFN sample exhibits a larger cell volume than the reduced PBFCN0.1, which is consistent with the samples before reduction. For instance, the lattice parameters of the reduced PBFN sample are calculated as a = 3.96778 Å, b = 3.9609 Å and c = 7.9220 Å and the calculated lattice parameters of the reduced PBFCN0.1 sample are a = 3.95862 Å, b = 3.95103 Å and c = 7.9050 Å. Then, the structural morphology and particle size distribution of the reduced PBFN and PBFCN0.1 samples were comprehensively examined via SEM and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM). As shown in Fig. 1(d), both samples exhibit a bulk size of ∼500 nm with the decoration of nanoparticles. Notably, there is a significant disparity in the size and coverage density of nanoparticles across the two samples. The reduced PBFCN0.1 sample, in particular, shows a significantly more uniform and extensive surface coverage. The results from the distribution statistics indicate that the reduced PBFCN0.1 sample exhibits a smaller average particle size compared to the reduced PBFN, with mean diameters of 63.21 and 77.42 nm, respectively (Fig. S3). The TEM images further substantiate the reduced PBFCN0.1 possesses smaller and more uniformly distributed nanoparticles (Fig. 1e). According to the BET analysis, after the thermal treatment in H2 atmosphere, the specific surface area of the PBFCN0.1 sample increased from 1.419 to 2.811 m2 g−1 (Fig. 1f). The increase in surface area is attributed to the formation of CoFe nanoparticles, offering a significant number of active sites for the hydrocarbon decomposition reaction, thereby boosting the rate of hydrogen generation over the SOFC anode. The X-ray energy dispersive spectrum mapping of Pr, Ba, Co, Fe, Nb, and O exhibits a homogenous distribution on the bulk phase of the reduced PBFCN0.1 (Fig. 1g). The presence of only Co and Fe at the nanoparticle sites further corroborates the formation of CoFe nanoparticles, which have an approximate size of 60 nm (Fig. S4). This size is notably smaller than that of the Fe nanoparticles, which are about 80 nm in diameter, observed on the reduced PBFN sample (Fig. S5). To further evaluate the nanoparticle evolution in layered perovskite ferrites, particularly under high reduction temperatures, we conducted a series of reduction experiments on PBFN and PBFCN0.1 samples. These samples were subjected to varying reduction temperatures, and their morphological changes were examined using SEM. Fig. 2 (a) illustrates the in-situ exsolution process mechanism in Co-doped layered perovskite ferrites. At a reduction temperature of 350 °C, we noted an absence of nanoparticle exsolution from the parent perovskite structure (Figs. S6a, S7a). However, a significant change was observed when the reduction temperature was increased to 500 °C. At this elevated temperature, both PBFN and PBFCN0.1 samples exhibited a decoration of nanoparticles with similar sizes (Figs. S6b, 2b). To confirm the elemental composition of these nanoparticles on PBFCN0.1, TEM and EDX mappings were employed (Fig. S8). The finding indicates that at a reduction temperature of 500 °C, the nanoparticles formed on the PBFCN0.1 sample consist of both Fe and Co, suggesting their simultaneous exsolution from the perovskite matrix. Upon further increasing the reduction temperature to 600 °C, the alloy nanoparticles on the surface of PBFCN0.1 undergo a transformation, resulting in smaller sizes and a denser distribution (Fig. 2c). These nanoparticles achieve a size similar with their final states observed at even higher reduction temperatures, specifically at 700 and 800 °C. It is well known that the intensity in EDX mapping reflects the elemental content of ions, revealing a significantly higher concentration of Co relative to Fe on the surface of the sample at a reduction temperature of 500 °C (Fig. S9a). As the reduction temperature reaches 800 °C, the intensity of both elements in the nanoparticles becomes comparable, indicating the occurrence of cation exchange, which leads to the replacement of some Co ions with Fe (Fig. S9b). In contrast, the morphology of PBFN exhibits no significant alterations despite the increase in reduction temperature (Fig. S6). Furthermore, the H2-TPR experiment of the four samples was conducted under pure H2 from 100 to 800 °C. As shown in Fig. 2(d), several distinct peaks are shown in the reduction process. The α peak, exclusively presents in the Co-doped samples and signifying the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+, is observed at temperatures of 214, 218, and 198 °C for α1−3 peaks, respectively, while the β peak, observed across all four samples and indicating the valence transition of Fe3+ to Fe2+, consistently manifests within the temperature range of 311 to 343 °C for the β0−3 peaks. With the increase of temperature, the PBCFN0.2 and PBCFN0.3 samples are decomposed due to their unitability structure. The γ peak, observed across the PBFN and PBCFN0.1 at ∼450 °C indicates the exsolution of Fe or CoFe nanoparticles, which is consistent with our SEM and TEM observation. Then, the signal enhancement beyond 500 °C can be ascribed to the incremental reduction of Nb5+ to Nb4+ and the exsolution of more nanoparticles. Fig. 2(e) illustrates the cation exchange process within layered perovskite ferrites at elevated reduction temperatures. It reveals that at a lower reduction temperature, around 500 °C, CoFe alloy nanoparticles are exsolved from the parent perovskite structure, with the Fe content being relatively low because of its high segregation energy. As the temperature rises, partial Co ions are substituted by Fe, resulting in a transition from larger to ultra-densely decorated, smaller alloy nanoparticles. 3.2 Surface chemistry and conductivity In order to analyze the valence states of the elements of Fe and Co, the reduced PBFCNx samples was examined using XPS observations. The XPS results reveal that the presence of Fe in three distinct valence states: divalent Fe2+ (approximately 709.7/723.2 eV), trivalent Fe3+ (approximately 711.7/725.4 eV), and metallic Fe0 (approximately 706.5 eV) (Fig. 3 a) [17,30]. The metallic Fe0 peak signifies the exsolution of metal nanoparticles at reduced atmosphere, consistent with the TEM findings. Moreover, with an increase in the Co dopant ratio to 0.2, a more prominent Fe0 peak appears in the XPS Fe 2p spectra due to the main phase decomposition. Table S5 provides an overview of the Fe ion percentages. The incorporation of a Co dopant at a ratio of 0.1 could lead to an increase in the Fe2+ ratio, consequently leading to a slight reduction in the average valence state of Fe. However, a higher concentration of Co dopant renders a variety of Fe-based oxides, implying that the observed valence state could differ depending on the specific site of detection within the mixture. In addition, as illustrated in Fig. 3(b), in the Co 2p spectra of the reduced PBFCNx samples, there are three distinct peaks corresponding to contributions to Co2+ (779.78 and 795.00 eV) and Co3+ (781.33 and 796.02 eV). It is notable that all three samples exhibit significant Co2+ and metallic Co0 peaks, with a minor Co3+ peak, suggesting that Co is easily reduced to a lower valence state at reducing atmosphere (Table S6). In the XPS O 1s spectra, three distinct peaks at ∼533.7, ∼531.7 and ∼528.6 eV can be identified, corresponding to adsorbed molecular H2O, lattice oxygen (Olattice) and adsorbed oxygen (Oadsorbed), respectively [31]. With Co doping, the proportion of Oadsorbed, linked to oxygen vacancies, increases from 56.01% to 57.77%, due to the decrease in the valence state of Fe (Fig. S10). Following the reduction process, both samples exhibit an increase in oxygen vacancies, where the Oadsorbed in reduced PBFCN0.1 further achieves 63.05%. This increase could be attributed to the exsolution of nanoparticles, which introduces more sites for oxygen adsorption (Table S7). To examine the Co doping effect on the electronic structures for the reduced PBFN and PBFCN0.1 samples, we resorted to XAS. Soft XAS at the O-K and Fe-L edges was firstly conducted in total electron yield (TEY) mode, which is notably sensitive to surface information of materials, with a probing depth of ∼5 nm [32]. Fig. 3(c) shows O K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra, normalized in the range of 520 to 550 eV. The peak A observed at 530.5 eV is attributed to the t2g orbital involved in the hybridization of Fe (Co) 3d and O 2p orbitals, while the peak B at 532.3 eV is associated with the absorption corresponding to the eg orbital in the Fe (Co) 3d-O 2p [33]. Both samples display a comparable peak for the t2g orbital in Fe (Co) 3d-O 2p hybridizations. In contrast, the reduced PBFCN0.1 sample shows a broadened electron density in the Fe (Co)3d eg orbital. This result demonstrates that the increment of transfer probability to eg orbital in the reduced PBFCN0.1, sugesting a more pronounced reduction of iron ions from a higher to a lower valency state, which is consistent with the XPS Fe 2p result [34]. The doublet peaks C and D, identified at 534.6 and 537.1 eV, correspond to the Pr (Ba) 5d-O 2p hybrid bands [33]. In addition, peaks E and F, situated at 541.7 and 544.9 eV, respectively, arise from the covalent bonding in Fe/Co 4sp-O 2p [35]. These peaks show consistent positions across both samples, indicating similar electronic environments. Fig. 3(d) presents Fe L-3,2 edge XANES spectra, normalized between 700 and 730 eV. Peaks a and c correspond to the Fe 3d t2g orbit, whereas peaks b and d are attributed to the Fe 3d eg orbit. No obvious difference in the peak positions and shapes of the spectra between the two samples, suggesting that the substrate perovskite remains stable and that the valence of Fe is slightly reduced [34]. Then, the soft XAS in FY mode is also employed to achieve a more extensive investigation of the surface properties. Relative to TEY mode, the FY mode of soft XAS allows for offers an enhanced probing depth, reaching up to approximately 200 nm into the material [36]. The reduced PBCFN0.1 exhibited abroad peak in O K edge XANES spectra in FY mode compared with reduced PBFN, indicating the increased structure distorts degree due to the cooperation of Co doping (Fig. S11). The electrical conductivity as a determinant of charge transfer plays a key role in the electrochemical oxidation reaction, then the conductivity of PBFN and PBCFN0.1 samples is evaluated by a four-probe method in air and H2, ranging from 800 to 400 °C. The inclusion of Co in PBCFN0.1 significantly enhances its conductivity in air, which is about 3–5 times higher than that of PBFN (Fig. 3e). Particularly at approximately 450 °C, PBCFN0.1 achieves its peak conductivity of 24.4 S cm−1, in contrast to PBFN, which exhibits a notably lower conductivity of just 5.1 S cm−1 at the same temperature. The enhancement in conductivity can be ascribed to the delocalization of electrons, a phenomenon closely linked to the more pronounced covalent character of the CoO bond relative to that of the Fe–O bond, facilitating a greater freedom of electron movement across the material due to enhanced orbital overlap and shared electron mobility [37–39]. This increase leads to a higher number of charge carriers, thereby boosting electrical conductivity [40]. Additionally, the conductivity profiles measured in air reveal a semiconductor-to-metal transition as the temperature rises, which could be attributed to the increased V O . . [41]. Based on the redox reaction described below, O o × + 2 h . ⇔ V O . . + 1 / 2 O 2 ↑ The rise in V O . . concentration leads to reduced electronic conductivity, accompanied by a decrease in electron holes. On the other hand, the conductivity of the two samples in a hydrogen environment is markedly lower than in air, potentially also due to oxygen vacancies created by the migration of oxide ions at high temperatures under reducing conditions, resulting in decreased conductivity (Fig. 3f). The XRD analysis shown in Fig. 1(b) reveals that the two reduced samples consist of a mixture of Fe or CoFe alloy and the main perovskite phase. Consequently, the conductivity mechanism encompasses two pathways for electron transfer: one involves surface metal transfer, while the other occurs through bulk phase transfer in the perovskite structure. The step-like conductivity profile could be attributed to the dual-pathway approach, resulting from the synergistic effects of the two distinct electron transfer modes. In addition, PBCFN0.1 exhibits higher conductivity than PBFN at all tested temperatures. This enhanced conductivity is advantageous for the charge transfer process, thereby facilitating improved kinetics in the triple phase electrochemical reaction. 3.3 Electrochemical performance of single cells utilizing various fuels SDC, notable for its good ionic conductivity and chemical compatibility with cobalt-containing perovskite oxide cathodes, functions as both the electrolyte and an ion-conductive phase [42]. Electrochemical evaluations of the PBFCNx-SDC anodes (with x = 0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3) were conducted based on SDC electrolyte-supported single cells. Fig. S12 show the cross-sectional morphology of these cells through SEM observation. The PBFCNx/SDC anode and SDC electrolyte have approximate thicknesses of ∼17 and ∼250 µm, respectively. To evaluate the performance of these single cells, current–voltage-power (I-V-P) and their corresponding EIS spectra curves with H2 as fuel were tested from 800 to 600 °C. The peak power density (PPD) of the PBFCN0.1 anode at 800 °C is recorded as 738 mW cm−2 (Fig. 4 a), which is significantly higher than that of PBFN (553 mW cm−2), PBFCN0.2 (640 mW cm−2) and PBFCN0.3 (605 mW cm−2). To assess the impact of Co-doping on electrode polarization, the Ohmic resistance of the electrolyte is deducted from the impedance spectra. EIS results depicted in Fig. 4(b) allow for the calculation of polarization resistance (R p) values, which are determined to be 0.0409, 0.0163, 0.0401, and 0.0408 Ω cm2 for PBFN, PBFCN0.1, PBFCN0.2, and PBFCN0.3, respectively. Furthermore, the EIS results were analyzed using the DRT technique [43] to effectively separate the electrochemical reaction process, providing insight into the distinct stages of the reaction (Fig. 4c). From the deconvolution of the electrochemical processes, three characteristic peaks, designated as PLF, PIF, and PHF are identified within the frequency range of 10−1–100 Hz. By referring to the similar research results previously reported, the PLF peak, situated within the 10−1–100 Hz range, is associated with the gas conversion process including gas adsorption and dissociation steps [44]. The PIF peak, found in the frequency range of 102–103 Hz, pertains to the process of the O2− incorporation and bulk transportation [45]. Meanwhile, PHF peaks that emerge at frequencies above 103 Hz are typically linked to charge transfer resistance and cathodic reaction processes [40]. The PLF peaks of the four materials display distinct variations, where the PBFCN0.1 anode is significantly lower than those of the other three materials. This suggests a quicker diffusion and activation processes of hydrogen, which plays a pivotal role in its superior electrochemical oxidation performance. Furthermore, cell with PBFCN0.1/SDC anode displays the highest peak PPDs among the four tested cell, exhibiting PPDs of 627 mW cm−2 at 750 °C, 526 mW cm−2 at 700 °C, 420 mW cm−2 at 650 °C, and 314 mW cm−2 at 600 °C (Fig. S13). Such performance is considerably higher than that of the SDC/GDC electrolyte-supported cell with various anodes recently reported including BL95CFN-SDC: (Ba0.9La0.1)0.95Co0.7Fe0.2Nb0.1O3− δ [46], LCFN-SDC: La0.6Ca0.4Fe0.8Ni0.2O3− δ -Sm0.2Ce0.8O2− δ [47], LLSFN0.05-SDC: La0.65Li0.05Sr0.3Fe0.8Ni0.2O3 − δ -Sm0.2Ce0.8O2 − δ [13], LSTNC-SDC: La0.52Sr0.28Ti0.94Ni0.03Co0.03O3 − δ -Sm0.2Ce0.8O2 − δ [8], PBFMNi0.3-SDC: (PrBa)0.95Fe1.6Ni0.3Mo0.1O3− δ -Sm0.2Ce0.8O2− δ [48], PSCFRu: Pr0.6Sr0.4Co0.2Fe0.75Ru0.05O3− δ [49], and NiO-Sm0.2Ce0.8O2− δ [50] as shown in Fig. 4(d) and Table S8. Moreover, the PBFCN0.1/SDC anode exhibits a remarkable potential for low-temperature operation, achieving significant PPD at 600 °C. The corresponding EIS results are 0.0297, 0.0379, 0.0763, and 0.1033 Ω cm2 at 750, 700, 650, 600 °C respectively (Fig. S14). From the DRT analysis of PBFCN0.1/SDC anode, both PLF and PHF associated with the exhibit marked thermal activation, leading to a significant increase in impedance. In addition, the cell demonstrates a stable operation at a current density of 540 mA cm− 2 under H2 across a 40-h discharge period (Fig. 4e). Then cross-section of the cell after discharge was examined via SEM, where the surface of electrode maintains its uniform distribution of ultra-high-density nanoparticles, without sings of segregation, showcasing the durable and robust interaction between the nanoparticles and the bulk phase of the electrode (Fig. 4f). At the anode side, H2 oxidation mainly contains three stages: (1) H2 adsorption at active sites, (2) O2− transportation through electrolyte to the anode, and (3) water formation and release [46]. The PBCFN0.1 material with ultra-high-density nanoparticles decoration harnesses the synergy of CoFe alloy nanoparticles and its perovskite matrix. These metal nanoparticles serve as active sites for catalyzing the adsorption and dissociation of hydrogen, showcasing low diffusion barriers for the dissociated hydrogen atoms, according to previous ab initio analyses [51,52]. This capability is crucial for the hydrogen oxidation reaction in SOFCs, where the nanoparticles enable hydrogen to effectively dissociate on their surface, allowing the dissociated hydrogen atoms to rapidly migrate to the metal-MIEC perovskite triple-phase boundary, where they react with oxygen ions and release electrons. This mechanism significantly enhances the electrocatalytic activity and expedites the kinetics of charge transfer, resulting in the high performance towards hydrogen oxidation reaction of the reduced PBCFN for SOFCs. In the realm of SOFCs, the capacity to utilize various carbon-based fuels significantly enhances their fuel flexibility and applicability. To evaluate the performance of PBFCN0.1-SDC anodes with C2H6 as the fuel, further electrochemical testing was carried out on single SOFCs. The results, as depicted in Fig. 5 (a), indicate that when C2H6 was used as fuel, the single cells could not achieve electrochemical performances as high as those with H2, suggesting a lower oxidation rate of C2H6 compared to H2. The single cells powered by C2H6 as fuel exhibits a similar trend with those using H2 as fuel, where PBFCN0.1-SDC anode demonstrates the best performance, achieving a PPD of 455 mW cm−2. Fig. 5(b) illustrates a comparison of the maximum power densities of four different anodes at temperatures of 800 and 750 °C. Notably, when the experiments were conducted at 750 °C, PBFCN0.1-SDC anode maintained a robust PPD of 336 mW cm−2, which is twice the performance of PBFCN0.2-SDC anode and three times that of PBFN-SDC and PBFCN0.3-SDC anodes (Fig. S15). Such disparity in performance is further corroborated by the EIS results (Fig. S16). Specifically, the total polarization resistance of the cell with PBFCN0.1-SDC anode is only 0.068 Ω cm2, which is notably lower than that of PBFN-SDC (0.207 Ω cm2), as well as the PBFCN0.2-SDC (0.143 Ω cm2) and PBFCN0.3-SDC (0.246 Ω cm2) anodes at 750 °C. Additionally, DRT analysis is conducted to gain a more comprehensive understanding of the EIS spectra. Fig. 5(c) shows five distinct peaks within the DRT curves, which have been labled as PLF, PIF1, PIF2, PHF1 and PHF2, respectively, indicating that the electrode reaction, when operating on wet C2H6, comprises at least five separate sub-steps. By referring the similar results reported in previous researches [53–55], the PLF peak in the low-frequency spectrum is closely associated with fundamental gas conversion reactions, including adsorption and dissociation at the porous electrode surface; the intermediate-frequency peaks, PIF1 and PIF2, are strongly linked to oxygen ion (O2−) incorporation and its bulk transport; the high-frequency peaks, PHF1 and PHF2, are indicative of electrochemical reaction processes, such as surface diffusion and charge transfer. The area enclosed by each peak in the DRT curve is widely recognized as indicative of the sub-electrode polarization resistance for each respective sub-step [56]. Thus, analysis of DRT technique clearly identifies the low-frequency sub-step, which is strongly related to the ethane adsorption and dissociation in the surface of the electrodes, is the predominant rate-limiting step. As illustrated in Fig. 5(e), the anode in a direct ethane fuel cell is the site of intricate reaction pathways, incorporating a blend of chemical and electrochemical transformations [17]. Chemically, the processes entail the decomposition of ethane to ethylene, the cracking of ethane to carbon and hydrogen, the hydrogenation of ethane to methane, and reforming reactions to generate synthesis gas; electrochemically, the reactions include the oxidation of ethane, methane, hydrogen, carbon, and carbon monoxide, showcasing the complexity of interactions at the anode. The outstanding performance of PBCFN0.1 is primarily due to its enhanced catalytic and electrocatalytic activities in facilitating complex anode reactions, a result of its ultra-high-density nanoparticles that offer a great amount of active sites for these reactions. In contrast, the limited exsolution of nanoparticles within PBFN-SDC, together with the observed structural decomposition in PBCFN0.2-SDC and PBCFN0.3-SDC, distinctly impairs their natural catalytic potential. Finally, the discharging curves of the PBFCN0.1-SDC cells using C2H6 as the fuel was obtained (Fig. 5d). It shows a 40 h stable run without obvious degradation, suggesting its good coke-resistant property. The XRD spectra of the anode material remain unchanged before and after durability test under C2H6 atmosphere, still composed of SDC and PBCFN0.1, demonstrating its good stability (Fig. S17). Raman analysis of the anode surface reveals the absence of characteristic D-band and G-band peaks, signifying no carbon deposition or agglomeration on the anode surface (Fig. S18). Furthermore, the cross-section of the cell was also examined by SEM after discharge. The electrode exhibits strong adherence to the electrolyte, showing no signs of cracking or any reactive occurrences. Moreover, there was no presence of carbon fibers or agglomeration on the anode surface, further confirming its robust catalytic stability and resistance to carbon deposition (Fig. S19). 4 Conclusions In summary, we demonstrated a controlled Co doping method to enhance the exsolution of nanoparticles in layered perovskite ferrite materials. (PrBa)0.95(Fe0.8Co0.1Nb0.1)2O5+ δ (PBFCN0.1) was selected as a typical perovskite for reducing in pure H2 under various temperature to reveal the nanoparticles exsolution evolution mechanism. In a reducing environment, Co promotes the reduction of Fe cations in PBFCN0.1, leading to the formation of CoFe alloy nanoparticles. This process is characterized by cation exchange, wherein rising temperatures result in the replacement of some cobalt ions with iron. These nanoparticles provide an abundance of reaction sites and exhibit good durability, particularly useful in the catalysis of hydrocarbons. The single cell with PBFCN0.1-SDC anode exhibit high performances in both hydrogen and wet ethane atmosphere. Notably, the performance under wet ethane atmosphere is significantly improved by 36%–70% compared to the original PBFN (e.g., a typical peak power density of 334 mW cm−2 at 800 °C). By providing insights into these temperature-dependent behaviors, the study presents a promising strategy for improving nanoparticle exsolution in layered perovskite ferrites, laying the groundwork for the creation of high-performance ceramic fuel cell anodes. coredata.dc:description: Nanoparticles anchored on the perovskite surface have gained considerable attention for their wide-ranging applications in heterogeneous catalysis and energy conversion due to their robust and integrated structural configuration. Herein, we employ controlled Co doping to effectively enhance the nanoparticle exsolution process in layered perovskite ferrites materials. CoFe alloy nanoparticles with ultra-high-density are exsolved on the (PrBa)0.95(Fe0.8Co0.1Nb0.1)2O5+ δ (PBFCN0.1) surface under reducing atmosphere, providing significant amounts of reaction sites and good durability for hydrocarbon catalysis. Under a reducing atmosphere, cobalt facilitates the reduction of iron cations within PBFCN0.1, leading to the formation of CoFe alloy nanoparticles. This formation is accompanied by a cation exchange process, wherein, with the increase in temperature, partial cobalt ions are substituted by iron. Meanwhile, Co doping significantly enhance the electrical conductivity due to the stronger covalency of the CoO bond compared with FeO bond. A single cell with the configuration of PBFCN0.1-Sm0.2Ce0.8O1.9 (SDC)|SDC|Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3− δ (BSCF)-SDC achieves an extremely low polarization resistance of 0.0163 Ω cm2 and a high peak power density of 740 mW cm−2 at 800 °C. The cell also shows stable operation for 120 h in H2 with a constant current density of 285 mA cm−2. Furthermore, employing wet C2H6 as fuel, the cell demonstrates remarkable performance, achieving peak power densities of 455 mW cm−2 at 800 °C and 320 mW cm−2 at 750 °C, marking improvements of 36% and 70% over the cell with (PrBa)0.95(Fe0.9Nb0.1)2O5+ δ (PBFN)-SDC at these respective temperatures. This discovery emphasizes how temperature influences alloy nanoparticles exsolution within doped layered perovskite ferrites materials, paving the way for the development of high-performance ceramic fuel cell anodes.
